name: Source Filmmaker
description: The Source Filmmaker (SFM) is the movie-making tool built and used by us here at Valve to make movies inside the Source game engine. Because the SFM uses the same assets as the game, anything that exists in the game can be used in the movie, and vice versa.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 / Vista (Windows 7 64 bit suggested) Processor: 3.0 GHz P4, Dual Core 2.0 (or higher) or AMD64X2 (or higher) Memory: 2GB (4 GB suggested) Graphics: NVIDIA GeForce 200 series card or better, or AMD Radeon 3000 series or better (NVIDIA GeForce 400 series or AMD Radeon 5000 series preferred) Monitor: 1366 x 768 (1920 x 1080 suggested) Hard Drive: At least 15 GB of Space Sound: DirectX 9.0c compatible USB headset with mic (suggested)

reviews.review_text: Relatively easy to get the hang of, and there's plenty of tutorials out there if you need help. There's also a huge fan base on YouTube for Source Filmmaker videos to help keep you motivated. Even if you've never animated before in your life (like me) I highly recommend this. With enough effort and time, anyone can make a SFM video. It's also really versatile- you can readily add custom textures, models, maps, anything! Not to mention the SFM Steam Workshop that is full of great content. Cannot recommend this software enough. Give it a go!

I've been using SFM for 35 hours in total and began learning from scratch without a shred of knowledge beforehand. Admittedly I have not created any animations longer than 3 seconds... but I have enjoyed playing about with creating renders/images for my profile or desktop backgrounds. I've experimented with posing, props and lighting.  I would love to finally animate something but alas it seems my computer (laptop) just isn't strong enough to handle the programme. My framerate is awful in the viewport, ranging from 2 to 4 FPS when trying to position the camera. Trying to watch back any animating I've done so far is nigh impossible as it's just too laggy to see what the movement is like.  Now it might sound like I'm being awfully critical and negative in my review but all-in-all, I LOVE this programme even if I am only to make still images. It's free and the workshop is full of amazing models people have created and supplied freely to the community making it truly a team effort.  I would definitely recommend this programme to others, as long as you think your computer is strong enough to pull it off.

Hell, this is one of the most diverse animation tool I've ever utilized in my life, and had given me quite a reputation for the videos I make in my Youtube. Of course, just like every starter of every tool, you'll feel like you're driving an airplane without any experience of piloting it, with you just looking at a perplexing cockpit layout, and if used incorrectly, you have the possibility of failing then crashing. But again, just like every user, once you've garnered a lot of experience with the tool, spending hours playing with it, you'll find yourself as an expert at this point.   The concept of this program is extremely easy to learn, which is probably an obvious statement since you might find a portion of Youtube all flooded with millions of SFM videos. The layout, just like what I've said above, might be scary to look at, but the process of learning the fundamentals of this tool is very quick. Well, of course, the speed of learning this tool would depend on how you capture the lectures of any tutorials.  However, there are some 'gripey' sides of the tools which could leave you in complete frustration.    Crashing.    Yes, the number one enemy of several animators and several other program users.  There are  COPIOUS  amounts of unintentional actions which could trigger this much hated term.  There are times that when you download workshop files then open the program, during the middle of the downloading process, the program crashes. There are times when you click on a particular button, for instance a model selection, it will crash. There are times when you export your polished videos, and during the download progression, it can crash.  There are times that when at random intervals the program crashes during your video production and when you open the file up again, the file corrupts. It CORRUPTS. Then it is permanently erased from your usermod directory.  But overall, the program is a 8.9/10. An excellent piece of software.

Source Filmmaker (SFM) is a free-to-use tool developed by Valve. It was used to make the 'Meet The Team' videos for TF2, the Intro videos for L4D 1&2, cutscenes for Portal 2, the DOD trailer and the CSGO trailer.  The main purpose of SFM is to make videos and animations, but can be used to produce stills/posters also. A major plus to this program is that assests from ALMOST ANY Source game can be imported and used in these videos (unless the engine has been severly modified, like Titanfall). There are also many videos on the Internet with tips and tricks on how to do things in SFM - from the fundamentals to the complex operations that make this such a powerful tool.  Two more things: This program is power-hungry! Make sure you have a good rig, otherwise it will be difficult to use. Don't give up. The learning curve for SFM is a harsh one...start with simple things and move up from there.

Till, I finally said F*** it and just worked in it regardless of lag, annoying yess, but I eventually learned to get around it, and almost make it seem as if I had none. Probably one of the easiest to learn (and free-est) animation platforms available. The Motion and Graph editors allow for percise motion creating and tuning very quickly. As supported by the lower-quality animations made near the SFM's launch in 2012, animating is a quite different experience than in most other software and it takes some getting used to, even if you are familiar with things like Blender or Maya. More natural animations would be best created using the Graph editor which handles things like acceleration, whilst rigid and straightforward animations are simpler to create using the Motion editor, which only handles raw motion. I might also mention how you can lock objects to other bones, making things like holding weapons or wearing hats much easier to animate.  Using the timless Source Engine as its base, the Source Filmmaker is a powerful tool for creating the animations of your dreams.

Source Filmmaker is one of the most useful programs I have ever seen when it comes to 3D animations. You could literally do almost anything with SFM; Want to make a picture of some monster made out of the gibs of the Team Fortress 2 characters? An super awesome sci-fi animation? It's possible with SFM. I personally use it mainly for images (as seen on my deviantART account, which is L45TF0R3RUNN3R) but I plan to try and get into animation. Of course, SFM has it's ups and downs. For example it can be difficult to use at first, but once you use it enough you can get the hang of it. There's the downside of some models such as Halo: Reach Elite models not being able on the workshop, but you can find them via many sites, including Facepunch. At least, I think that's what it's called, so forgive me if I got the name wrong.  Overall, SFM is a great and mostly simple yet somewhat complicated 3D animation/image-making program. I'd recommend it for amateur image-makers or animators.

This is a fantastic tool.  It has hundreds of uses, from making you tube animations to thumbnails to just really great artwork that can be shown off.  People complain about the difficulty of the program, and it's difficult because it was not meant to be used by beginers, this is the softwere a multi-billion dollar company uses to make promotional content.  Giving it a negative review would be like giving a $3,000,000 camera a bad review because it was meant to film multi-million dollar movies, not something in your backyard.  Valve and Just people that like the Program have made hundreds of hours of Tutorials teaching you how to properly use it, and like any other activity, practice makes perfect, i myself have no used it much as my steam library was randomly deleted, and i just haven't gotten a chance to re-install until now.  Some of the most epic and most beaustiful artworks ive seen on steam, and even around the internet were made using this program.  This is much simpler than trying to use photoshop to re-create your favorite tf2 loadout, and much more imersive than just taking a screen-cap in a game.  Source film maker earns a 9/10 in my book, just becasuse of how well balanced the tools are, the avaliabilty of content through both the commuinty workshop, and 3rd party webistes, the avaliablility of tutorials and learning programs, and just the sear limitlessness of what can be created if you just set your mind to it.  Overall, this program is great, worth a download, if your impatient, leave it alone, do not hate because you are to lazy to watch a few hours worth of helpful videos. It's a top of the job film maker. It has earned itself a high reputation, recently. It's easy to use once you get the hang of it after a few practices if you are really devoted to create your own videos.  Although, you are going to need a powerful decent computer/laptop to run and save your work with this program considering you need at least 15 GB of space and a high graphics card. Because less powerful computers aren't going to stand a chance. The program would still work but the chances of it crashing is a lot likely to happen and loading assets takes a lot while longer.   Overall, the quality and graphics are very high. Moving props and skeletons uses a similar system to Garry's Mod's Bone Manipulator but slightly more sophisticated and plus this software is produced by Valve and inturn they use it to create their videos. Tutorials are notebly separate from the program so an internet search is required to find them. I recommend this software if your computer/laptop is powerful enough to tolerate it.

Source Filmmaker is a great way to begin in animating, and it's completely free. It's easy once you know what you're doing, and it has plenty of content. Next to that, you are also able to add content to the game from the workshop, or things you downloaded from the Internet.  If you aren't any good at animating, you think it's too much work, or you feel you're not good enough, don't worry. Source Filmmaker allows you to make posters (images from scenes that you put together). However, some models can have issues when you export a poster. Instead, make sure you aren't in the motion editor (where there is a lot of green at the bottom. Motion editor reduces quality slightly) and instead export it as an image.  Now my main issue is that Source Filmmaker takes forever for an update to be released. Sometimes they add new things, other times they improve other things. But it can be several months between updates, whether large or small.  If you're expecting a game, the only thing you're able to do is go into a very early version of Team Fortress 2, alone, without anything to fight. This is mostly for recording gameplay animations without having to do it manually, and it can save a lot of work.  Overall, this is a fantastic way to start animating, and it's a great tool for an experienced animator to use. If you wanted to make a few animated videos or maybe a couple of cool posters, then this is the program you should use.

Valves Source Filmmaker is a comprehensive tool for cutscene animation and still images using assets compatible with their game engine. The interface is optimised for productivity and quick iteration times, perfectly suited to a single animator or studio animation team alike. The available game assets provide a kickstart that springboard projects from storyboard to screen, and the SFM includes Perforce integration so you can track and share your projects easily.

Updated Review at 166 hours on 10-16-15   9/10  It is a fantastic software. Like my old review (down there!), I feel this is very, very good at its purpose: animation. Using it has a little to be desired, but its YouTube tutorials and thriving community are very supportive in terms of helping. The controls are a tad finicky, but once you use it for a bit, it generally flows quite well.  Another great aspect of the program is the great Workshop. The Workshop is one of the greatest things, as you can use it expand the universe you build with.  It's also great for making dank meme pictures, as well as profile pictures for your favorite games. :)  Would definitely recommend.   Old review!  Overall : 9/10  The program, although it has cumbersome, crude tutorials and controls at best, it still shines at what it is meant to do: ANIMATE. Once the controls click, the whole process feels like a breeze, and is, in turn, very satisfying. If it just doesn't work out, then there's Valve's official tutorials too! Takes a while to understand its complexity, despite its simple-looking interface. The diversity and unique things you can create makes it something worth trying out.

my first few hours of using this software were daunting. terrifying, and overall confusing... after watching valves official tutorials and experimenting myself, i find that SFM is very intuitive, functional, and as proven by many youtubers, can be used to produce very high quality videos.  I myself am not skilled in animating, but with the help of SFM, i'm getting the hang of it. It's certainly not 'easy' but after just a few hours, i understood the basics and with not much time under my belt, i have made a couple good test animations.  the only main issue i've had is frequent crashes when using a lot of usermod items, but it always autosaves whenever i do ANYTHING, so it's more an inconvienence than anything.  Without a doubt, worth any prospective animator, or filmmakers time. or even just a gamer, it makes me appreciate SFM films on youtube a lot more,

I recommend this to almost every Blender, and MMD animator ^^ SFM is easy to work with, and easy to animate once you get the hang of manipulating model bones, i'm still working on posing hands and spawning particle effects, but read some posing tutorials, basic tutorials and you'll be a professional in no time! I perfer you practice manipulating the legbones, armbones, hair-jiggles, and handbones, not the fingerbones straight off the bat.  Since this stage is only the Beta Stage, things WILL change, SFM MAY crash, it's either you go with the crashing, or wait until the official SFM releases.   SFM gives you more uses for the CTRL, SHIFT, and the Scroll Wheel for 3D animation progression control.  You can also make Sonic Game remakes. I KNOW. Almost everythe thinks the Sonic Fandom sucks, but you can make animation that looks like some Sonic Games! (e.g: Sonic Generations)

Which brings me to the only downside of this incredible tool. Typhoon Cinema and all the other cinemas out there ruin SFM for me. Because they produce disgusting clickbait thumbnails that attract little children. And most, if not  all  of the uploads on their channel aren't made by them. Otherwise this is an almost perfect tool to use for 3D animation. I rate this a 10/10. Thank you for reading this review! :)

Valve's Source Filmmaker is an amazing free to use software that allows you to use models from games like Team Fortress 2, Half-Life, and Left 4 Dead and make your own animations with them. Everything is at your disposal with SFM. The layout of the program is easy to use and not to mention how great the fans of the program are. People who use SFM have the ability to upload their own models. maps, etc. to the Source Filmmaker Workshop for others to use and that is just amazing. To be able to go to the Workshop and find exactly what you need is just amazing. Source Filmmaker is a good gateway into animation for noobies such as myself, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking to learn animation or to just mess around and make derpy animations with their favorite Valve characters. Animating. It's hard. Especially if you're not good at drawing. Source Filmmaker takes away the drawing. Because you don't need it!
